title: Close to home
subtitle: Relief funds support frontline workers, pandemic research
body:
Their first date ended on the wrong note.  

Sneha Shah was an medical intern at the Veterans Administration Medical Center, and Trevor Minton was a professional celloist, so their hectic schedules made it a challenge to meet. So they agreed to have coffee on a Wednesday morning and walk around the Tennyson neighborhood in Denver. Eventually, Shah reluctantly asked Minton if they could go to his apartment: she needed to change into scrubs for her first night shift. Before she left, Minton was even kind enough to let her attempt to play a few notes on his cello. Which she did — badly, as she recalls.    

Now a couple for three years, Shah and Minton faced their biggest challenge together yet.  

When the coronavirus hit this spring, Shah knew as a medical resident she would be on the frontlines of the pandemic. But suddenly the pandemic hit close to home.   

A CU Boulder alumnus, Minton earns most of his income performing with organizations like the Colorado Ballet and Opera Colorado. Those major music events had all but evaporated during the shutdown. And, as a gig worker, it meant he didn’t qualify for government assistance. 

The couple wasn’t sure how to face this uncertainty, but they knew they would find a way together.  

“In our culture, I find that asking for help sometimes is really hard to do, especially when you're asking for financial help. Trevor is a very strong person, but I definitely saw a change in him. As you can imagine for any person who has a significant job loss, it was just terrifying to think that he might have to give up cello as a career. The stress of that was a big burden.”  

Shah’s modest income as a medical resident wasn’t enough to cover their expenses. So she applied for the CU Anschutz’s Medical Resident Relief Fund to ask for help covering housing costs so the couple would have one less thing to worry about.  

Thanks to generous donors, the Medical Resident Relief Fund supports medical residents and fellows through unexpected hardships related to the pandemic. Since April, the fund has helped 40 residents and fellows cover childcare costs, auto repairs, board-certification fees for delayed exams and extended trainings, mental health services and more.  

CU Anschutz has other COVID-19-related funds that support workers in pulmonary health care, emergency medicine and pandemic research.   

“The donors who supported the Resident Relief Fund have not only provided short-term relief, but they've provided a long-lasting impression that humanity is good. I know that sounds like a big statement, but honestly, when you're a doctor, there are some days that are really hard; then to see your loved one’s suffering, you just feel helpless.” 

In addition to relief funding, Shah received a care package through Project Lift, a CU Anschutz program that connects health care professionals to mentor and provide help to medical students and fellows during COVID-19.  

When the pandemic first started, Shah worked overnight shifts in the makeshift ICU unit at UCHealth University of Colorado Hospital for COVID-19 patients. Shah thought she might receive a few premade meals she could reheat at work. Instead she received fresh bread and flowers, soup, candles and chocolate from a pediatric nephrologist from Children's Hospital Colorado.  

Generous support like this has helped alleviate some of the fears the couple felt in the early days of the pandemic and has allowed them to focus on the future.  

“The university and our campus has done a fantastic job of putting our physical safety and emotional well-being first. In the future, we would love to pay it forward because we've been inspired by these donors who were generous enough to give. We were just so beyond thankful to have the assistance when we needed it the most.”
